definition: A statement describing the method of distribution and access provided by the Distributor or Publisher.
The URL where the digital object can be accessed via a service endpoint, API, etc.
The organization sharing, publishing, or otherwise responsible for providing access to the digital object.
The type of service endpoint used for distribution.
The TDIS unique identifier for the associated collection.
Date the digital object was originally created. Must conform to the ISO 8601 standard.
The date the digital object was last updated. Must conform to the ISO 8601 standard.
Date the metadata record was last updated. Must conform to the ISO 8601 standard.
Date the digital object or metadata record was submitted to TDIS. Must conform to the ISO 8601 standard.
The TDIS unique identifier for the digital object.
License associated with the digital object.
How often the content is updated.
Constraints or restrictions on use of the digital object.
Version number of the digital object.
Organizational affiliation for the responsible point of contact.
Dept under the Contact Affiliation
Email for the responsible point of contact.
Name of a person who is a responsible point of contact.
use: Required for Collection, Optional for Artifact, Layer, and Model

definition: Work phone number for the responsible point of contact.
The role(s) of the point of contact toward the digital object and its management.
Placename from GeoNames (http://www.geonames.org).
The scale of the dataset
Coordinates for the bounding box describing the spatial extent covered by the digital object, in decimal degrees.
validation: Array: Decimal Degrees or Geometry: Polygon

definition: Time period to which the data refer as a single date-time or an interval. Must conform to the ISO 8601 standard. This reflects the time period covered by the data, not the dates of coding or making documents machine-readable or the dates the data were collected. Also known as the "span" covered by the data, this may reflect the dates during which an event occured.
How accessible is the data?  Is the data readily available online or must it be requested from the host?  Are there tools online to easily download the files? If it fully accessible as a web service?
example: 1 - Data access requires request to use at the location of data.

definition: The type of geospatial boundary associated with the digital object.
The unique identifier for a geospatial boundary unit of a particular type, such as a name or code.
A assessment of the level of completeness of the dataset.
example: Is the dataset missing significant features, unfinished but moderately complete, or mostly complete?

definition: The name of a person or organization who should be cited as contributing to the initial creation of the digital object. Also referred to as an "author" or "contributor".
Is the data in a stage that can easily be used for disaster response? Does it require a significant amount of processing or is it ready to use?
An account of the digital object. The description may include an abstract, a table of contents, or a free-text account.
example:
"This point dataset represents high water mark observations made by USGS field staff after Hurricane Harvey in Sept 2017  (Sept 9 - Oct 10). 
High water mark types include debris lines, seed lines, mud lines, direct observation, and other types.

definition: Subject matter keywords
Vocabulary for subject matter keywords listed in Keyword Term.
Dimensionality choice of a terrain model (1D, 2D, 3D, or combos) created prior to running hydro model computations.
The type of model.
A description of the purpose for the creation of this digital object and/or the expected use.
example: For future flood forecasting, predicting severity of future floods, and delineating floodplain maps

definition: The name of the software used to create or work with the digital object.
use: Required for Model, Optional for Artifact, Layer

definition: The version of the software used to create or work with the digital object.
use: Required for Model, Optional for Artifact, Layer

definition: A name given to the digital object.

A statement of any changes in ownership and custody of the digital object since its creation that are significant for its authenticity, integrity, and interpretation. The statement may include a description of any changes successive custodians made to the digital object.
example: Data collection and creation of dataset performed by USGS. Additional reclass field added by UTCSR.
